section.title: Vector Equations

introduction.definition: A matrix A is square if it has the same number of rows as columns. In other words, A is an n \times n matrix, for some n.

section.subsection:
Vectors
The term vector is used widely in mathematics and physics. Here, a vector will simply mean an ordered list of real numbers. In linear algebra, we represent vectors most commonly as a column matrix, a matrix with dimensions 1 \times n, i.e. a matrix with 1 row and n columns. Similarly, a row vector is a m \times 1 matrix, a matrix which has 1 columns and m rows.
First, we will consider vectors with two entries. The set of all vectors with two entries is denoted by \mathbb{R}^2 (read r-squared or simply r-two).
Two vectors in \mathbb{R}^2 are equal if their corresponding entries are equal.
Let \vec{u}, \vec{v} be vectors. Their sum \vec{u} + \vec{v} is the vecotr obtained by adding the corresponding entries of \vec{u} and \vec{v}.
Let \vec{u} be a vector, c \in \mathbb{R}. Then, the scalar multiple of \vec{u} by c, c\vec{u}, is the vector obtained by multiply each entry of \vec{u} by c.
The number c \in \mathbb{R} is called a scalar.
Often, it is simpler to write vectors horizontally rather than vertically, but it is necessary to keep the vertical convention. In this case, we identify a column vector with an ordered tuple of numbers. For example,
\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{is equivalent to} \quad (1,-3)
More generally,
(b_1, \dots, b_n) \quad \text{is equivalent to} \quad \begin{bmatrix} b_1 \\ \vdots \\ b_n \end{bmatrix}
Note that (b_1, \dots, b_n) is not a row vector.

subsection.title: Geometry of Vectors in \mathbb{R}^2
subsection.p: Every point in the plane is completely determined by an ordered pair of numbers, so there is a one-to-one correspondence between points in the plane (a,b) and vectors \begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix}.

subsection.title: Vectors in \mathbb{R}^3
subsection.p: Vectors in \mathbb{R}^3 are 3 \times 1 column matrices, and can be represented geometrically as points in space.
